The Peale Museum, Baltimore





Peter Cooper built his “Tom Thumb” for direct trans-Atlantic service. One valu-
demonstration locomative in Baltimore, able “import” were immigrant passengers
but then the railroad began to make some by the thousands who got off the steamers
of its own equipment, and finally, Ross and went directly to waiting trains for
Winans established a big locomotive works transport further west. In the 1870s the old
near the Mount Clare shops, and supplied P.W. &B. Railroad, now part of the Conrail
not only the B & O Railroad but others. system, developed extensive port facilities
Wendell Bollman learned his trade in the in Canton along the same lines. The West- ‘
engineering department of the railroad ern Maryland Railway completed the story
and then founded the Patapsco Bridge and in 1904 with its Port Covington complex.
Iron Co. which made and exported steel The railroads were the driving force in
bridges. Another railroad following the modernizing and expanding the port of

Jones Falls northwards, now Conrail’s
Northern Central line, was the stimulus for
the establishment of cotton mills at Mount
Vernon and Woodberry, and the Poole and
Hunt Machine Works, also at Woodberry.

Baltimore for almost a century.

The railroad’s influence on the develop-
ment of commerce was no less profound.
The first terminus of the B & O Railroad
was at Pratt and Light Streets near the
steamboat docks, and there were spur
tracks leading throughout the Inner Harbor.
Then, in 1845 the B & O Railroad ran a
branch line through South Baltimore to
Locust Point and set about building a
complete port facility with piers, ware-
houses, grain elevators, and coal docks.
After the Civil War the railroad financed
the Baltimore & Bremen Steamship Line

The “Tom Thumb”’, American railroading began in Baltimore with this locomotive

o,
